ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Improved charge injection of pentacene transistors by immobilizing DNA on gold source-drain electrodes

Affiliation.OrgDivision: School of Materials Science and Engineering
Key Lab of Advanced Display and System Application, Ministry of Education

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We successfully optimized the charge injection of pentacene-based organic thin-film transistors with bottom contact by immobilizing deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) on gold electrodes. The single-stranded DNA having mercapto group (-SH) was used as the modified layer by molecular self-assembly onto the surface of gold electrodes. The threshold voltage is −10 V, and the field-effect mobility reaches 0.34 cm2/V s, which is comparable with that of typical top-contact devices. Mechanism of performance improvement is due to the high carrier density in contact region attracted by the phosphate group on the DNA backbone increasing the tunneling probability for improved charge injection. Furthermore, the introduction of modified layer significantly enhanced the grain size of pentacene that is beneficial for charge transport, which also is responsible for the improved device performances.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In recent years, much effort has been devoted to the development of organic thin-film transistors (OTFTs) with high performance due to their prominent advantages, such as low production cost, mechanical flexibility, large area devices, and low temperature fabrication [1–4]. Several potential applications based on OTFTs are envisioning including flat-panel displays, radio frequency identification tags, and sensors [5–7]. Top contact (TC) and bottom contact (BC) are two basic device structures according to the difference of deposition sequence between source/drain electrodes and organic semiconductor. In terms of TC-OTFTs, organic semiconductor layers are usually suffered from the solvent erosion during the metal photolithography process, although it often exhibits better device performance than that of BC devices. Therefore, the BC configuration is highly desirable based on the consideration of process [8], as it not only significantly improves the stability of OFETs but also dramatically reduces device cost.

Charge injection is a crucial charge process during OTFT operation that significantly influences on the device performance. Especially to these short-channel devices, the performance of BC-OTFT is worse than that of TC-OTFT, which is ascribed to the poor contact properties between metal electrode and organic semiconductor [9–12]. Since the contact resistance of the BC structure is greater than that in the TC geometries, any attempt at lowering the injection barrier intended to enhance the OTFTs performance is arguably as important as efforts directed at increasing carrier mobility of the intrinsic organic semiconductor [13–15]. Campbell and coworkers [16] introduced an elegant way to lower the charge barrier, which is depositing self-assembled monolayers on top of the electrodes prior to the deposition of the semiconductor layer. From then on, some functional thin-film materials have been reported to modified source/drain electrodes to improve charge injection [17–19].

It is desirable to consider using natural and renewable materials for modifying the contact properties. DNA is an excellent candidate for having prospects in various optoelectronic applications, since it is a naturally occurring, renewable, and biodegradable polyelectrolyte. In 2009, DNA was used as an insulating layer in OFETs [20]. And then in 2011, DNA served to improve electron injection and also functions as a hole-blocking layer in PLEDs [21]. Based on these functions, DNA can be used to modulate the injection of a single type of charge carrier. In this work, we demonstrated the improved BC-OTFT by immobilizing single-stranded DNA having mercapto group (SH-ssDNA) on the surface of gold electrodes. The SH-ssDNA serves as the modified layer to improve the charge injection that results in the enhancements of electrical characteristics in both saturation current and carrier mobility. The morphology of the thin-film on the various regions was investigated through atomic force microscopy (AFM).

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: Pentacene sample was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich Company, while chemical solvents with analytical reagent grade were used without further purification. Phosphate buffer solution (PBS) (10 mM, pH 7.4) was freshly prepared before use. The SH-ssDNA (5′—SH-TATA CGGT TCGCGC—3′) used in this experiment was synthesized by Sangon Biotech (Shanghai) Co., Ltd.

OFETs with a BC configuration were fabricated according to the following procedure. Heavily doped n-type silicon wafers (0.01–0.15 Ω cm) covered with a thick layer (300 nm) of thermally grown SiO2 were acted as the substrate and gate electrode. The Si wafer was ultrasonically cleaned in acetone and ethanol for 15 min, and then was rinsed with deionized water, and finally baked at 120 °C for 10 min. Before deposition of pentacene, gold electrodes (25 nm) were patterned through shadow masks at a rate of 0.1 nm/s by thermal evaporation. The width and length of the patterned channel were 2,700 and 180 μm, respectively. Subsequently, 2 μl of SH-ssDNA stock solution was pipetted on the surface of the gold electrodes. The stock solutions of DNA molecules were prepared in PBS and the concentration was 50 μg/ml. Then the device should be rinsed by deionised water for over 2 min and the residual water was removed by an air gun with high pressure. Finally, pentacene film (30 nm) was deposited via thermal evaporation with the rate of 0.03 nm/s under a base pressure of 10−4 Pa. During pentacene deposition, the substrates were kept at room temperature. The step-by-step BC-OTFT with gold electrodes modified by SH-ssDNA fabrication procedures are illustrated in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1
Schematics of the BC-OTFT with gold electrodes modified by SH-ssDNA fabrication

The electrical characteristics were measured with Agilent 4155C semiconductor parameter analyzer at room temperature in ambient air. Morphological characterization was carried out by atomic force microscopy (AFM; SPI 4000) in tapping mode.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
As we all know that one of the most important factors in determining the device performance is the formation of the metal/organic interface. It is because of the charge injection through the interface into the semiconducting layer depending on the quality of the contact condition. On account of the mechanism of the OTFT, the source-drain current (I D), will show a linear behavior at the small bias. Nevertheless, the nonohmic contact property makes the behavior of nonlinear at low source-drain voltage (V D). Figure 2a shows the electrical characteristics of the untreated sample with bare gold electrodes, which suggest that the device could be operated successfully as a typical transistor. One can easily observe the current crowding at low V D, which corresponds to the nonohmic behavior of the I DS in the linear region. This indicates the contact, which exists between the electrodes, and the organic active layer is nonohmic contact. This poor contact is a disadvantage for charge to inject into the organic semiconductor from the metal electrodes. The carrier mobility at saturation region is calculated to be 0.21 cm2/V s from equation (1),

where W and L are the channel width and length, respectively, C i is the insulator capacitance, V T is the threshold voltage, and μ is the field-effect mobility [22, 23].

Figure 2b represents the electrical characteristics of the organic field-effect transistors with the Au electrodes treated using SH-ssDNA. We note that I D increased almost linearly at small V D, as a consequence, a much better contact was formed between the organic active layer and the source and drain electrodes. The saturation current at V D = −60 V reached up to −47 μA, which is more than two times larger than that of the untreated sample. The charge mobility of the device is calculated to be 0.34 cm2/V s.

As expected, we can conclude that the immobilization of the SH-ssDNA on the gold electrodes gives rise to a decrease in injection barriers, because I DS increases almost linearly at small V D for the electrode-treated samples, while it increases nonlinearly for the untreated samples. In addition, the conductance of the device with treated contacts is much larger than that of the device with bare gold contacts at low voltage. The improvement of the conductance at the low V D region indicate the optimized charge injection.

We also plot I D–V D curves in linear region for the OTFT biased at a V D of −10 V in Fig. 2. The mobilities and threshold voltages in the linear region are extracted from the transfer curves.The field-effect mobility can be calculated by (2), 2

where all terms remain as previously defined. For the device with untreated contacts, the field-effect mobility was estimated to be approximately 0.05 cm2/V s, which is much smaller than the saturation field-effect mobility. It is poor charge injection that leads to this large discrepancy in field-effect mobility for the two regions of device operation. For the device with modified contacts using SH-ssDNA, the linear mobility was about 0.15 cm2/V s, which is close to the saturation mobility indicating enhanced charge injection.

The transfer characteristics of the organic field-effect transistors with the untreated Au surface, and Au surface treated using SH-ssDNA at V G of −50 V are shown in Fig. 3. The enhancement is evident in terms of threshold voltage between the two samples. The threshold voltage of untreated sample with bare gold electrodes is obtained as −17 V. After modifying the contact surface with SH-ssDNA, the threshold voltage decreased down to −10 V, because the injection barrier between the metal electrodes and the organic active layer was lowered.
Fig. 3
Transfer characteristics of devices with bare gold electrodes and gold electrodes modified with SH-ssDNA at V D = −60 V

Here, we find one reason may be responsible for the experimental results. It has been proved that the phosphate group on the DNA backbone imparts a net negative charge in the DNA molecules [24], which attracts holes from the organic semiconductor. Due to the high carrier density, the resistance of the contact region is lowered. In addition, the tunneling probability for the injection of charges is also increased. Therefore, immobilizing SH-ssDNA on gold source-drain electrodes can play a role in improving the injection characteristics.

Commonly, BC-OTFT is difficult to achieve comparable performance as that of TC-OTFT for the greater contact resistance. We fabricated TC-OTFT with Au electrodes to compare to the performance of BC-OTFT with bare Au electrodes and treated Au electrodes. The parameters of different devices are listed in Table 1. The results show that the BC-OTFT represented a lowest threshold voltage and a greatest saturation current when the Au electrodes were treated with SH-ssDNA. Moreover, it yielded a field-effect mobility (0.34 cm2/V s) that was to the level of the TC-OTFT (0.36 cm2/V s) fabricated at room temperature with bare Au electrodes.

It is often suggested that the growth of pentacene molecules on a conductive surface leads to the formation of a disordered film [25], whereas the molecules grown on a dielectric surface are highly ordered. We carried out AFM measurement of pentacene grown on SiO2 to Au and Au modified with SH-ssDNA, respectively, as shown in Fig. 4a, c and the corresponding line profiles are shown as Fig. 4b, d. As noted, pentacene growth on the untreated device displays a typical morphology with slightly small crystallites. In the SH-DNA-treated device, larger pentacene crystallites form the conduction path in the channel region. Moreover, a 10 nm height difference of pentacene can be observed between the untreated substrate and treated one. On the other hand, pentacene growth on top of Au electrodes appears to be influenced by the upper DNA molecule layer. In general, pentacene on SH-DNA-treated device reveals larger grains and smoother layers than that on untreated device. The discrepancy in the morphology of the pentacene film on the SiO2 insulator and on the Au electrodes may probably influence the carrier injection from the source and drain electrodes to the pentacene film.
Fig. 4
AFM images of pentacene grown a on SiO2 and Au c on SiO2 and Au modified with SH-ssDNA and the corresponding line profiles of the images

Figure 5 represents the AFM images of pentacene grown on Au and modified Au with SH-ssDNA, respectively. Figure 5a shows a relative small pentacene grain size (average diameter 200 nm) on bare Au. As shown in Fig. 5b, the grain size of pentacene on the SH-ssDNA-modified Au is about 500 nm; this improvement would lead to an increase in saturation current and mobility of the devices. Hence, it is obvious that both the film morphologies between electrodes and insulator, and the size of the grain of pentacene result in the enhancement of electrical performance.
Fig. 5
AFM images of pentacene grown on Au and Au modified with SH-ssDNA

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, the electrical properties of the organic thin-film transistors with modified source and drain electrodes fabricated using SH-ssDNA were investigated. After modifying the contact surface with SH-ssDNA, the mobility and the saturation current increased up to 0.34 cm2/V s and 47 μA, respectively. They are both better than that of the devices with conventional Au electrodes. The charge injection property was enhanced by immobilizing DNA on electrodes, lowering the threshold voltage and increasing the field-effect mobility in BC-OTFTs, even achieving comparable performance as TC-OTFTs. The pentacene morphology was further investigated by the AFM. It can be concluded that the larger grain size of pentacene crystallites on electrodes turns out to be an additional parameter increasing the saturation current and the mobility.
